response.answer_text: There probably isn’t any single explanation for the crash but there are at least four contributing factors. First, there was no meaningful regulation of the stock market. Literally anything was possible. Things like insider trading and market manipulation were legal and occurred with frequency. Second, it was common for wealthy people to form syndicates for the express purpose of manipulating stock prices driving prices up and down to realize what we now consider illegal profits. Third, there was no distinction between commercial banking (banks) and investment banking (brokerages). You could open a brokerage account and borrow money from the bank to pay for your purchases. Fourth, credit for major purchases is a relatively new innovation. Previously, your grandfather or great grandfather didn’t get a mortgage to buy a house, they saved until they could pay cash. With the introduction of credit at the turn of the century not only could people obtain a mortgage for a house, they could buy stocks on margin. It was not unusual for people to buy stock on 90% margin. That works okay as long as the market is going up. However, when the market goes down the lender gets nervous and calls the loan. If you can’t pay your margin balance the lender will sell your securities to protect itself. It won’t be picky about the price. Naturally, if buyers think the price is going down they won’t buy and sellers keep dropping the price to get a buyer. This leads to a downward spiral in the market. A series of laws and regulations were enacted in the 1930s which addressed these issues. Glass Steagel (which prohibited the combination of commercial and investment banking) was repealed during the Clinton administration. That was (in my opinion) a mistake that we will pay for. A good book on the subject of the ’29 Crash is The Day the Bubble Burst. The book is probably thirty years old but still in print (check Amazon).

The answer to that question would take a book, or more likely many of them. Anyone who says they know “the reason” the market crashed is only grasping on one single aspect of the overall economy and market situation that had been building up for over a decade, and fixating on a single event, mistaking it for “the cause.” There was no single cause. WWI resulted in farm overproduction across the world driving commodity and farm prices to punishingly low levels. “Family farmers” in the US sold to factory farms and large landowners and flocked to the cities with few skills, no money, and they found jobs in the new factories making cars. Congress was intent on passing the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act in an effort to prevent “cheap foreign-made goods from flooding US markets,” and on both Black Friday and Black Monday, articles appeared in the NY Times reporting that Hoover was going to sign the bill when it reached his desk, as it did in 1939, but just the newspaper articles noting that fact may - emphasis on ‘may’ - have been enough to act as the catalyst that tripped the already precarious market - it had peaked in August, 1929 and was already declining by October - into a crash. Then it took nearly three years, until mid-summer 1932, before the market bottomed, down 90% or so. Hoover signed Smoot-Hawley, which crushed global trade, and drove Germany into the arms of Hitler. Hoover also raised taxes in the teeth of the storm, so to speak, well after the markets had crashed, something most would agree was the exact opposite of ‘the right thing to do.’ And oh, so much more. Please read a few of the many books written about 1929. There is no “single” answer, and there are many opinions, but no one can or has definitively pointed to any single reason for the crash.

Beginning with Lyman J. Gage, The U.S. Secretary of the Treasury began to deposit the United States' reserves directly into favored commercial banks to maintain liquidity and attempt to keep interest rates low (please note that this was actually illegal at the time).  Secretary Leslie M. Shaw continued this to an even greater degree leading up until 1907, when the rate of these deposits began to decrease, resulting in a decrease of bank reserves and money in circulation, precipitating the Panic of 1907. By 1910, the ratio of commercial bank reserves to liabilities stood at 14.2%. Further elasticity was desired, so soon came The Creature from Jekyll Island, better known as Federal Reserve Act of 1913. In 1920, The Governor of The New York Federal Reserve, Benjamin Strong, began aggressive asset purchases. When he passed away in 1928, his successor, a more hawkish George L. Harrison slowed asset purchases and precipitated America's Great Depression.  As you can see in the above graph, interest rates for 10 Year U.S. Treasuries were raising until The Federal Reserve entered open market operations to expand the money supply and purchase the bonds. In-so-doing, it generated excessive inflation which resulted in malinvestment and the worst stock market bubble of the 20th century. After the Federal Reserve intervened in the 1920's, they never stopped their policy of inflation. By 1933, it was clear that The Federal Reserve had expanded the money supply beyond to the point that The United States didn't have as much gold as they had in currency which was redeemable in gold. To solve this problem, Franklin Delano Roosevelt signed Gold Reserve Act into law. This law made "gold hoarding" illegal, and changed the value of the U.S. Dollar from $20 per ounce of gold to $35 per ounce of gold, and The U.S. Dollar was no longer redeemable by citizens for gold-- it was only redeemable by foreign governments. Overnight the federal government had devalued the currency nearly 50%, and made it illegal for U.S. citizens to own gold. Even today, when people buy gold coins and gold bullion, they are buying "collectors' items," as The Gold Reserve Act of 1933 was never repealed. After World War II, The United States had solidified its spot as a world superpower. During this period, The U.S. Dollar was "as good as gold." The Federal Reserve printed money to maintain steady inflation.  This continued until about 1970, when, again, The United States government realized that all of the gold in Ft. Knox could not satisfy the demands of individuals abroad holding U.S. Dollars. In a move that shocked the world, The U.S. defaulted on its debt, and abandoned the gold standard (note: the U.S. government kept the gold, though). Stagflation followed, and Paul Volcker used Inflation targeting, to fight it. Unfortunately, though, this created significant volatility in the rate of interest on loans.  Today, the interest rate has been nearly flat with a slope of zero for almost a decade.

Most stock market crashes have similar causes, and the crash of 1929 followed the usual pattern. A bull market had led many people to invest heavily, often with borrowed money. The use of leverage in a market is inherently destabilizing - since people can potentially lose more than their total investment, people investing on margin tend to jump ship at the first sign of trouble. In the days leading up to "Black Thursday" (October 24, 1929), there were several days of heavy trading volume and substantial up and down price swings. Decades later, an economist named Jude Wanniski found that these swings correlated with the debates in the Senate of the Smoot–Hawley Tariff Act, which had already passed the House of Representatives. Fears that the Act would pass and cause a trade war caused a substantial drop the morning of Black Thursday. Several leading bankers intervened to buy shares to support the market, a tactic which had successfully stopped the panic of 1907. But the newspaper coverage over the weekend spooked investors, and come Monday panicked highly-leveraged investors were clamoring to get out of the market. October 28 and 29, "Black Monday" and "Black Tuesday" both saw double-digit drops. Given the level of speculation and leverage, a drop in the market was inevitable. But, with the benefit of hindsight, fear around the impact of the Smoot-Hawley bill was the trigger that drove the timing of the crash.

Market prices for equities reflect hopes and beliefs in addition to measurable financial returns.  Market crashes reflect sudden revisions. Look at the real economy in 1929.  Railroad track miles in the US peaked in 1926, so 1929 was not a great time to be in steelmaking or railroad construction.  Moving into the 1930s, the spread of automobiles meant the elimination of huge numbers of jobs making railcars and other heavy equipment, and the revaluation of huge amounts of real estate that used to be price by proximity to rail facilities.  Cars also resulted in the elimination of some 50,000,000 horses between 1915 and 1945, which added to the dislocations.  Some time around 1929 people must have begun to see this. When large numbers of people are thrown out of work in the same place at the same time, their networks for finding new jobs are destroyed.   No large organization has any incentive to help these people, they are simply left to fend for themselves.   Ted Levitt at the Harvard Business School used to pose the question "Why did the railroads not survive the depression by reinventing themselves as transportation companies and going into automaking?"  The powerful Durant family who owned the Union Pacific was one of the major investors in General Motors, and probably a significant number of other businesses that did less well.  Some of the employees found other successful jobs, and probably a significant number did less well.  Major economic dislocations are ...well... depressing.

The autumn of 1929 witnessed the biggest stock market crash in history with people losing billions and opening the path to the longest economic depression in the industrialized world. When it comes to duration and aftermath, it is even bigger than the 2008 financial crisis (I’ve written about it here: The 2008 global financial crisis explained in simple terms.). The years after the first world war were characterized by wealth and a rise in industrial production and growth which were naturally accompanied by a rising stock market fuelled with speculation that didn’t truly justify the current fundamentals. A bubble is defined as an unjustified rise in market value. But before discussing the crash and the aftermath, we have to discuss the main causes that led to this crisis. Overheating economy.Overheating, overconfidence, and overproduction were three words to describe most of what was happening. First of all, the unjustified rise in stock prices meant that the buying of the shares was purely for speculative reasons. The buyer didn’t really care about the prospects of the company in a few years, he was only looking to join the party with everyone else. Of course many industries beforehand showed increases in profits (namely, steel production and railway), but people went overboard with the buying activity. Second of all, overconfidence of market participants led to the fact that they didn’t have a plan B in case there was a crash, everyone was sure that markets will continue to go up forever. And third, industries were overproducing products which led to a glut. This means that the excess supply will force prices lower and thus companies suffered. Easy credit.This is self-explanatory and everytime we see the word easy credit, we know that there is trouble ahead. During the years leading up to the crisis, there was a huge growth in bank credit and loans. Buying on margin also fuelled this bubble as it is the act of borrowing money from stockbrokers while providing very little collateral. Interest rates.Weeks before the crash, the Federal Reserve raised interest rates from 5% to 6%. Rising rates means costlier borrowing costs for companies, thus, lowering profitability and economic growth. Jobs can also be lost due to the impacted earnings. A fuel from the London Stock Exchange.Days before the the US stock market crash, a top British investor named Clarence Hatry and some of his associates were jailed for fraud, prompting the London Stock Exchange to crash and infecting its American peer with pessimism. By this time, it was very unstable and so any bad news could have a magnified negative effect. Panic.As is the case in every crisis, panic amplifies the negative effects and worsens the impact. Amidst the panic and the crash, people started to withdraw their funds from banks (or tried to). This effect led banks to fail even quicker than one would expect  Source: https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/stock-market  Needless to say, stocks started to gradually decline until October, 1929, where the fall grew more serious. During that time, panic started to further amplify the effects and even though big investment companies and banks tried to stabilize the market by buying shares, the market didn’t stop there and kept heading south.

There were so many reasons but you’re asking for the “main” reason. Well if you’re an Elliott wave follower, the reason would be we reached the top of a multi-decade wave 3. There’s truth in that but there’s also truth in this: You could buy stock with just 10% cash in 1929. In other words, the exchange would let you borrow 90% of your stock purchase. In other words, the primary cause was OVER LEVERAGING - too much debt and liquidation when they couldn’t pay. Here are the mechanics: (1) As soon as you had a decline, you owed money to the exchange because your ‘equity’ was below 10% in your position.. (2) They requested payment to bring your equity up to 10% (a “margin call”) (3) You don’t have the money to bring your account up to 10% equity (4) The exchange liquidates (sells) your position so they don’t lose any more money. (5) The selling of your positions means more the market goes down and there are more ‘margin calls’ to other over-leveraged people who bought with just 10% down (6) They don’t have the cash to bring their equity up to 10% (7) More “liquidation” (selling) occurs … And on and on it goes until... CRASH! In February, 2018 “margin” debt was at the highest level ever - even more than 2008 when the market declined 50%:  Will the result of over-leveraging be ‘different’ this time? I doubt it.

I’m surprised that there aren’t already hundreds of answers. But the only true answer is that there were a great many causes. One problem is that a great many people assume that it was the market crash caused the Great Depression. They will look for correlations that don’t answer your question. Another problem is that for all the smoke, there was very little fire. Few people in the country owned stocks in the market and loosing their gambling money in the crash should have been inconsequential. However, having said that, a great many banks and savings associations decided that the stock market was not gambling but rather a perpetual motion source of wealth. This is how most victims of Ponzi schemes get taken for all their money. Of course, they were gambling with other people’s money and not their own, And an added incentive to gamble was that they could buy stock on a very low 10% margin. This is the leverage that greatly increases profits and losses. (Same as with the Great Financial Crisis, with its home-ownership liar loans, mergers and acquisitions, and default credit swaps a century later. ) It certainly didn’t help that there was a considerable amount of self-dealing and fraud in the market as well. The pump-and-dump was a favored insiders scheme. Of course, there was no deposit insurance to cover any losses back then. When the market collapsed people who owned no stocks investments lost all of their “safely and prudently saved” savings. With their money “simply gone” the country now had a liquidity crisis. This is where the Federal Reserve dropped the ball. But they weren’t even playing in the game. The “idee fixe” at the time was that “the government that governs the least, governs the best.” Interfering with markets was just so wrong on so many levels. (Sound familiar?) It wasn’t until the election year of 1932 that the Fed, Congress, and the White House began to move and by then it was too late to save Herbert Hoover. Part of this problem was the Gold Standard, which was supposed to be a neutral mechanism that could control inflation and depression by controlling foreign exchange rates. As one country became too rich with gold it would print more paper money. This “easy” money caused inflation of its native prices to rise and encouraged buying cheaper foreign goods. When the foreign sales were settled in gold, the gold reserves dropped, causing the central bank to stop printing money. They also raised interest rates so as encourage foreign investment that would reverse the flow of gold. Problem now was that the US had most of the world’s gold as a result of WW1. It could afford to lose a lot of it and still print money. But rules is rules, and so they had to stop printing money, which caused a liquidity crisis to become worse, and raised interest rates, which crippled any efforts to rebuild the economy as there was no money to repay the loans. So, with a lot of blame to go around as to the cause of the Depression and all of it beginning with the stock market collapse, what caused the market collapse? Some of them are: low interest rates, low margin rules for buying, insider corruption, an unrealistic reliance on market discipline, and “irrational exuberance.” (Sound familiar?) Remember, the stock market is not the economy. It’s a gambling casino that is supported by its addicts.

When the crash hit in October, 1929 and stock prices were in free fall, brokerage houses went to the buyers for more money to cover their positions. If they couldn’t pay they were sold out, losing everything. Brokers were in the same position since most of them bought the stock they sold to the public on margin. The old ticker tape process for stock market activity was running hours late so no one had any idea of what their stock was worth in real time causing a panic among investors.

In The Great Crash, 1929 John Kenneth Galbraith argues that the 1929 crash was precipitated by “… rampant speculation in the stock market, that the common denominator of all speculative episodes is the belief of participants that they can become rich without work”. (The Great Crash, 1929 - Wikipedia) For a different interpretation, you can refer to Milton Friedman (economist). In his classic work with Anna Schwartz, A Monetary History of the United States, he postulated that “… the Federal Reserve’s monetary policies were largely to blame for the severity of the Great Depression”. (The Great Depression According to Milton Friedman | Ivan Pongracic Jr. includes an interesting description of both interpretations). As in any complex phenomenon, there are multiple factors that collaborate in triggering the observed outcome. Relevant to our current-day debates, Protectionism is also cited as a cause of the Crash (although some analysts see it as a reaction to it). Causes of the Great Depression - Wikipedia offers a wide-ranging review of the different theories.
